trans-unit.target: >[AZURE.IMPORTANT] The scalability and performance targets listed here are high-end targets, but are achievable.

trans-unit.source: In all cases, the request rate and bandwidth achieved by your storage account depends upon the size of objects stored, the access patterns utilized, and the type of workload your application performs.
trans-unit.target: In all cases, the request rate and bandwidth achieved by your storage account depends upon the size of objects stored, the access patterns utilized, and the type of workload your application performs.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to test your service to determine whether its performance meets your requirements.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to test your service to determine whether its performance meets your requirements.

trans-unit.source: If possible, avoid sudden spikes in the rate of traffic and ensure that traffic is well-distributed across partitions.
trans-unit.target: If possible, avoid sudden spikes in the rate of traffic and ensure that traffic is well-distributed across partitions.

trans-unit.source: >When your application reaches the limit of what a partition can handle for your workload, Azure Storage will begin to return error code 503 (Server Busy) or error code 500 (Operation Timeout) responses.
trans-unit.target: >When your application reaches the limit of what a partition can handle for your workload, Azure Storage will begin to return error code 503 (Server Busy) or error code 500 (Operation Timeout) responses.

trans-unit.source: When this occurs, the application should use an exponential backoff policy for retries.
trans-unit.target: When this occurs, the application should use an exponential backoff policy for retries.

trans-unit.source: The exponential backoff allows the load on the partition to decrease, and to ease out spikes in traffic to that partition.
trans-unit.target: The exponential backoff allows the load on the partition to decrease, and to ease out spikes in traffic to that partition.

trans-unit.source: If the needs of your application exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, you can build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data objects across those storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: If the needs of your application exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, you can build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data objects across those storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: See [Storage Pricing Details](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/storage/) for information on volume pricing.
trans-unit.target: See [Storage Pricing Details](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/storage/) for information on volume pricing.

## Partitions in Azure Storage
Every object that holds data that is stored in Azure Storage (blobs, messages, entities, and files) belongs to a partition, and is identified by a partition key.

trans-unit.source: The partition determines how Azure Storage load balances blobs, messages, entities, and files across servers to meet the traffic needs of those objects.
trans-unit.target: The partition determines how Azure Storage load balances blobs, messages, entities, and files across servers to meet the traffic needs of those objects.

trans-unit.source: The partition key is unique within the storage account and is used to locate a blob, message, or entity.
trans-unit.target: The partition key is unique within the storage account and is used to locate a blob, message, or entity.

trans-unit.source: The table shown above in [Scalability Targets for Standard Storage Accounts](#scalability-targets-for-standard-storage-accounts) lists the performance targets for a single partition for each service.
trans-unit.target: The table shown above in [Scalability Targets for Standard Storage Accounts](#scalability-targets-for-standard-storage-accounts) lists the performance targets for a single partition for each service.

trans-unit.source:
Partitions affect load balancing and scalability for each of the storage services in the following ways:
- **Blobs**: The partition key for a blob is container name + blob name.
trans-unit.target:
Partitions affect load balancing and scalability for each of the storage services in the following ways:
- **Blobs**: The partition key for a blob is container name + blob name.

trans-unit.source: This means that each blob has its own partition.
trans-unit.target: This means that each blob has its own partition.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can therefore be distributed across many servers in order to scale out access to them.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can therefore be distributed across many servers in order to scale out access to them.

trans-unit.source: While blobs can be logically grouped in blob containers, there are no partitioning implications from this grouping.
trans-unit.target: While blobs can be logically grouped in blob containers, there are no partitioning implications from this grouping.

trans-unit.source: - **Files**: The partition key for a file is account name + file share name.
trans-unit.target: - **Files**: The partition key for a file is account name + file share name.

trans-unit.source: This means all files in a file share are also in a single partition.
trans-unit.target: This means all files in a file share are also in a single partition.

trans-unit.source: - **Messages**: The partition key for a message is the queue name, so all messages in a queue are grouped into a single partition and are served by a single server.
trans-unit.target: - **Messages**: The partition key for a message is the queue name, so all messages in a queue are grouped into a single partition and are served by a single server.

trans-unit.source: Different queues may be processed by different servers to balance the load for however many queues a storage account may have.
trans-unit.target: Different queues may be processed by different servers to balance the load for however many queues a storage account may have.

trans-unit.source: - **Entities**: The partition key for an entity is table name + partition key, where the partition key is the value of the required user-defined **PartitionKey** property for the entity.
trans-unit.target: - **Entities**: The partition key for an entity is table name + partition key, where the partition key is the value of the required user-defined **PartitionKey** property for the entity.

trans-unit.source: All entities with the same partition key value are grouped into the same partition and are stored on the same partition server.
trans-unit.target: All entities with the same partition key value are grouped into the same partition and are stored on the same partition server.

trans-unit.source: This is an important point to understand in designing your application.
trans-unit.target: This is an important point to understand in designing your application.

trans-unit.source: Your application should balance the scalability benefits of spreading entities across multiple partitions with the data access advantages of grouping entities in a single partition.
trans-unit.target: Your application should balance the scalability benefits of spreading entities across multiple partitions with the data access advantages of grouping entities in a single partition.

trans-unit.source: A key advantage to grouping a set of entities in a table into a single partition is that it's possible to perform atomic batch operations across entities in the same partition, since a partition exists on a single server.
trans-unit.target: A key advantage to grouping a set of entities in a table into a single partition is that it's possible to perform atomic batch operations across entities in the same partition, since a partition exists on a single server.

trans-unit.source: Therefore if you wish to perform batch operations, consider grouping entities with the same partition key.
trans-unit.target: Therefore if you wish to perform batch operations, consider grouping entities with the same partition key.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, entities that are in the same table but that belong to different partitions can be load balanced across different servers, making it possible to have a large table with greater scalability.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, entities that are in the same table but that belong to different partitions can be load balanced across different servers, making it possible to have a large table with greater scalability.
